Introduction
People with learning disabilities (LD) often experience extreme health inequalities, poor health outcomes, and poor access to healthcare despite their greater health problems and needs.

The confidential enquiry into the premature deaths of people with learning disabilities (2013) found that the quality and effectiveness of health and social care given to people  with  LD  has  been  shown  to  be  deficient  in  a  number  of  ways.  These inequalities continue to be identified through the work of LEDER and it is recognised in the LEDER annual report 2019 that there is still significant improvement required.

The  MSE  NHS  Foundation Trust  are  committed  to  looking  after  all  patients  with respect to their individual needs and requirements. However, it is recognised that patients who have a LD may need additional support, intervention and assistance exceeding the level of care provided as a matter of course within the usual hospital environment.
Scope

Many  people  with  learning  disability  are  able  to  access  health  services  without difficulty; however, it is essential that assistance and special consideration is given to those who require additional support when using health services to make sure that reasonable adjustments are made that ensure an equal outcome of care.

The purpose of this policy is intended to minimise risk and maximise good practice by ensuring that the actual and potential physical health needs of patients with LD are identified and met appropriately.

In addition this policy is to support the Trust when working with patients with LD, to communicate effectively with them in order to provide the information and advice they require to ensure the hospital stay is as uncomplicated as possible.

This policy applies to the practice of Trust staff in the provision of services to people with LD accessing wards/ departments. It offers protocols to guide practice in specific situations and tools for practitioners to use in meeting the care needs of patients with LD.
Definitions

table_items.text: The Government define a learning disability as including the presence of:

The DSM4(Diagnostic & Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders 2000) states that as well as intellectual functioning being markedly below average ( IQ 70 or less) that difficulty functioning in 2 or more of the following areas would be expected: Communicating Caring for self Living at home Relating to others Directing self Using community resources Academic functioning Working Health and safety And that the condition started before the age of 18. (This can be seen as those within the bottom 3 to 5 % of the population based on IQ and social functioning levels) The Government emphasizes that the use of IQ scoring alone is not a sufficient reason to decide whether someone should be provided with additional specialist support, but assessment of social functioning and communication are to be taken into account, (Valuing People, DoH 2001). The definition covers adults with autism who have learning disabilities, but not those with a higher level autistic spectrum disorder who may be of average or above average intelligence – such as some people with Asperger's Syndrome, (Valuing People, DoH 2001).
Autism is a lifelong developmental disability that affects how a person communicates with, and relates to, other people. It also affects how they make sense of the world around them. The
term autistic spectrum disorder describes all diagnosis on the spectrum including classic autism, Asperger's syndrome and high functioning autism.
Vulnerable Adult / adult at risk of abuse

The purpose of adult safeguarding is to prevent harm and reduce the risk of abuse or neglect to adults with care and support needs. The statutory framework introduced under the Care Act applies to any person aged 18 or above who: Has needs for care and support (regardless of the level of need and whether or not the local authority is meeting any of those needs), Is experiencing, or is at risk of abuse or neglect, and as a result of those needs, is unable to protect themselves against the abuse or neglect or the risk of it.

data.text: Roles and Responsibilities

MSE joint Safeguarding Committee – To provide assurance to the trust in regards to compliance with all local and national guidance regarding service provision for patients with LD in an acute healthcare environment.
Associate Director for Safeguarding Service (Group Role)

The development and leadership of a robust culture of safeguarding practice across the MSE group, providing strategic and corporate direction including complex professional advice on matters relating to safeguarding individuals at risk:
Ensuring that national and local recommendations from emergent safeguarding work are implemented across the Trust and are included within its policies and practice

Leading a robust culture of safeguarding, directed through the approved MSB safeguarding governance reporting structure, including the Safeguarding Operational Groups, Learning Disabilities Operational Group, Children and Adults Safeguarding Committee in Common and the Quality Committee in Common

Learning  Disability  Lead  -  To  act  as  the  strategic  lead  in  the  development  of equitable and high-quality health care for adults with learning disabilities within acute care across the MSB Group.

Learning Disability Acute Liaison Nurse – To help and support clinical areas to meet the needs of people with LD when they are admitted / attend for treatment / appointments. They have specialist expertise which will enable clinical teams to plan and support the patients care to ensure that they have a positive experience.
Matrons - will in the absence of the ward manager review the decisions made by ward staff and assess the appropriateness of the reasonable adjustments that have been

made and ensure that the Ward Manager / Matron Checklist is completed (See Appendix 7). When required the matron will authorise additional resources. Matrons will be involved in the escalation of concerns, and support teams to plan and deliver appropriate care thus ensuring positive patient experience.

Ward / Department Manager - will review the decisions made by ward staff and assess the appropriateness of the reasonable adjustments that have been made and ensure that the Ward Manager / Matron Checklist is completed (See Appendix 7). When required the matron will authorise additional resources. Matrons will be involved in the escalation of concerns, and support teams to plan and deliver appropriate care thus ensuring positive patient experience.

Ward / Department staff - The admitting nurse needs to undertake a comprehensive assessment, to identify individuals needs such as communication and support needs to ensure continuity of care and to maintain appropriate levels of support during the hospital admission. This may include the utilising specialist assessment tools in addition to the standard ward assessment tools. See appendices 1-5.
Process
Patient Flagging
5.1.1 All patients with diagnosed LD, who access services across the Trust can be flagged on the patient administration systems.

5.1.2 Any patient who attends services across the group who has a diagnosed learning disability and does not currently have an alert will be referred to the (LDNS) with the patients consent. If the patient lacks capacity this referral would be considered to be in the patient's best interests.

5.1.3 Any patients, who are diagnosed with ASD but do not have a learning disability e.g. high functioning autism or Asperger's syndrome, can opt to be added to the flag if they choose to do so. Please record this request in the notes.
5.1.4 Please be aware that patients may have more than one patient alert flag.
5.1.5 These flags are in place to alert staff to the diagnosis and to prompt further action in regards to support for the patient.
Hospital Passport See Appendix 1

5.2.1 Hospital Passports should be requested on presentation of the person with learning disability at any point of engagement with services. If the person does not have a hospital passport they can be accessed on the external hospital website or you can contact the safeguarding team for a blank copy.
5.2.2 The purpose of the Hospital Passport is:

To aid communication of additional / specific care needs that health care staff should know about when the person with learning disability and / or ASD first presents for a consultation, treatment or investigation
To promote continuity of care and flexibility of service provision, according to individual need
To ensure that “reasonable adjustment” is made in accordance with the Disability Discrimination Act 2005, to ensure equality of access to healthcare for people with learning disability and / or ASD

5.2.3 Remember equality does not mean the same treatment it means making reasonable adjustments to give people with a disability an equal outcome. Failure to do so would be a breach of the law. Disability Discrimination Act 2005
Communication

5.3.1  Up to 90% of people with learning disability have communication difficulties and this is a key factor behind the poor recognition of their health needs and abilities of services to meet those health needs for example the recognition and response to pain and distress.
Accessible information

5.4.1 All organisations that provide NHS or adult social care must follow the Accessible Information Standard by law. The Accessible Information Standard aims to make sure that disabled people have access to information that they can understand and any communication support they might need.
5.4.2 As part of the Accessible Information Standard, organisations that provide NHS or adult social care must do five things.
5.4.3 They must:
Ask people if they have any information or communication needs, and find out how to meet their needs.
Record those needs in a set way.
Highlight a person's file, so it is clear that they have information or communication needs, and clearly explain how those needs should be met.
Share information about a person's needs with other NHS and adult social care providers, when they have consent or permission to do so.
Make sure that people get information in an accessible way and communication support if they need it.
There are accessible resources available on intranet and internet that may support the patient.
(Please see accessible information policy for your site).
General Principles of Communication
5.5.1  Consideration for the following should be made when communicating with patients with a learning disability:
How the patient normally receives and gives information e.g. Pictures, Makaton, Picture Exchange Communication (PECS) and Symbols
Speak to the person with learning disability directly
Speak clearly and not too fast
Keep sentences short, make key messages simple and avoid jargon
Avoid abbreviations
Avoid using negative words such as don't, can't and won't as these can be confusing and harder to understand
Check information has been understood.

The average gap between a person listening and then responding during a conversation is three seconds. People with learning disability may need longer to think about what has been said and formulate a response
If you are giving new information only use one “information giving” word or phrase per sentence e.g. “blood test”
Try to avoid abstract concepts. Use concrete terms wherever possible
People with learning disability may find nouns easier to understand
People with learning disability may have difficulty recalling when things happen so use anchor events e.g. Christmas and birthdays or holidays to help them remember
If you ask a question that offers a choice of answers be aware that person may choose the last one as it was the easiest to recall. You can check by asking this question again in a different way
Make sure the conversation has a clear beginning, middle and end.
Ensure a familiar person is present where possible to reassure and assist with communication
Ensure familiar person is present where possible when procedures and diagnostics are explained and performed
Check likes and dislikes and allergies and other important information with primary carers
Make reasonable adjustments to care delivery where appropriate.
Assessment of Communication

5.6.1 All patients with learning disability should have an assessment of their communication that is documented where possible at pre assessment for planned admissions and within 24 hours of admission for unscheduled admissions. Additional communication tools and aids required should be documented eg large print, hearing loops, picture menus and provided on admission for planned admission and within  72 hours for unscheduled admissions.
5.6.2 The more limited the communication, the more important observation, monitoring and intervention for activities of daily living including continence, nutrition and pain.

5.6.3 Ideally patients with significant communication needs will have communication assessments and care plans in the community this information must be shared with the acute hospital service if available.
Specialist Assessment Form See Appendix 2

5.7.1 For those with patients who due to cognitive impairment or physical illness have severe communication difficulties, the completion of Specialist Assessment Form (SPA) (Appendix 2) is required at pre assessment for planned admissions and within 24 hours of admission for unscheduled admissions. The SPA is intended to enable staff to identify distress cues. The SPA should be completed with the patient and primary carer.
5.7.2 A copy of the SPA form should be maintained within the patient record.

5.7.3 When a patient with learning disability is referred by the Trust to another service within the Trust or a community service then information about communication requirements should be shared at the point of referral.
Abbey Pain Scale See Appendix 3
5.8.1 The pain scale is an instrument designed to assist in the assessment of pain in patients who are unable to clearly articulate their needs.
5.8.2 The staff recording the scale should, therefore, observe and record in the scale while the patient is being moved, e.g. during pressure area care, while showering, etc.
5.8.3 Record results in the patient's notes. Include the time of completion of the scale, the score, the staff member's signature, and action taken in response to the assessment.
5.8.4 A second evaluation should be conducted  hour after the intervention taken in response to the first assessment, to determine the effectiveness of any pain relieving intervention.

5.8.5 If, at this assessment, the score on the pain scale is the same, or worse, undertake a comprehensive assessment of all the facets of the patient's care, monitor closely over a 24 hour period, including any further interventions undertaken, and, if there is no improvement, notify the medical practitioner.
Hospital Communication Book
5.9.1 This book is available in ward areas and from the LDNS and on the trust intranet. It is a practical communication tool that people can use to help communicate together.
5.9.2 NB Difficulty in communication should not be confused with lack of capacity.

5.9.3 In addition staff should promote the use of easy read information and also access resources on the internet to enable them to assist in the explanation and understanding of treatments and procedures etc.
Reasonable adjustments and communication
5.10.1  Examples:
Access to a Learning Disability Nurse Specialist
Hospital Passports being recognised and used.
Hospital Communication Book
Identification of family / carer needs
Pre admission ward visit
Open Visiting (where appropriate)
Learning Disability flagging system
Flexible appointment times
‘Getting to Know you' visits
Access to easy read information and other accessible formats
Staff training in Learning Disability awareness
Consent
5.11.1 Please refer to MCA and Consent policy

5.11.2 The fact that a patient has a learning disability does not alter the need to obtain informed consent. Many patients with a learning disability do have the capacity to give informed consent - it should not be assumed that they cannot. They must be supported to make decisions; and all practical help must be given before anyone treats them as lacking capacity.
5.11.3 If the patient lacks capacity to make decisions, the Trust has a duty to act in that patient's best interests. The LDNS can support and advise staff in assessing capacity if required.

5.11.4 If the patient does not have the capacity to give consent, treatment is lawful providing it is in their best interest; staff should refer to and abide by the Mental Capacity Act Policy and Consent Policy.
5.11.5 An Independent Mental Capacity Advocate must be instructed and then consulted, for people lacking capacity who have no-one else to support them (other than paid carers).
5.11.6 People with LD may have to be deprived of their liberty to obtain essential treatment and keep them safe. The safeguarding team will support and advise staff in applying for DOL's safeguards.

5.11.7 Where there is an appointee with lasting power of attorney (LPoA) or an appointed court of protection (COP) Deputy – staff will need to inspect or obtain a copy of the documentation to confirm that this is valid and to determine if there are any restrictions on the decisions that they can be made.

5.11.8 The position regarding consent in an emergency situation is no different for a person with a learning disability - ultimately the attending doctor makes the decision to proceed provided it is in the patient's best interest.

5.11.9 Specific legal advice must be sought wherever there are doubt about proposals for certain treatments e.g. sterilisation and the necessity for obtaining consent in relation to such proposals see the References for a DoH guide for people with a learning disability. Please contact the LDNS or Safeguarding Team for any necessary support.
5.11.10 It is totally unacceptable to offer inferior treatment because:
The patient has a learning disability
There are difficulties in obtaining informed consent
5.11.11 There are several tools that can support this process to ensure patients receive the appropriate support.
https://www.livingwellessex.org/media/704163/mca-guide-nhs.pdf
Deciding right is a useful NHS tool that can be used to support health professionals navigate this process. The link is below and available on the trust intranet.
https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.indigomultimedia.decidingright&hl= en_GB&gl=US
Emergency Department Pathway
5.12.1 Triage & Management

5.12.2 All patients with learning disability will be triaged where possible within 15 minutes of arrival. The triage nurse will ensure that the patient has adequate time to be triaged appropriately. The triage nurse will escalate to the emergency nurse practitioner or nurse in charge when additional assistance is required. The triage nurse will complete the ED checklist (see appendix 4) and request the Hospital Passport which will be copied with the patient and or carer consent and copy placed in the casualty record.

5.12.3 The triage nurse will inform the nurse in charge (NIC) of ED that a patient with learning disability is attending. The NIC will review with the triage nurse the most appropriate management of the patient. This will take in to account any additional needs of the patient in terms of communication, pain assessment, distress and length of wait and most appropriate place to wait. This assessment and plan will take place with the patient and carer if appropriate.

5.12.4 The  management  plan  will  take  into  consideration  the  need  to  make  reasonable adjustments to ensure equality of access and outcome of care for patients with a disability within the emergency department. This may mean
Patients with learning disability are seen sooner than their clinical priority indicates

Patients with learning disability who are distressed or may become distressed in a strange environment will be offered a cubicle if possible where clinical presentation may not usually indicate the need for a cubicle.
5.12.5 The management plan will be documented in the patient record and reviewed hourly or earlier at the request of the patient or carer.
5.12.6 Pain relief will be offered and administered where appropriate.
5.12.7 It is important for staff to note that not all patients with LD will need additional support from LDNS. However if advice or support is required please contact the site LDNS.
Investigations

5.13.1  Where an x-ray or other investigation is required Emergency Department (ED) nursing staff will liaise with the department and support the patient to the relevant department or investigation. The nursing staff will ensure that waiting time and waiting area are appropriate and make arrangements for transfer back to the ED as required. The nursing staff will provide explanation about the investigation and ensure timely review of investigation results and reports.
Discharge from Emergency Department
5.14.1  Due to the vulnerable nature and / or enhanced needs of this client group ED staff must ensure on discharge that the following are taken in to consideration
Transport home is safe and adequate
Long waits for transport are avoided where possible.
Patient comfort and safety is considered if unavoidably long waits for transport including dietary and personal hygiene needs
Clear follow up instructions must be given to the patient or primary carer including contact numbers and changes to care and treatment, including new medication.

Where a follow up review is indicated the preference for return should be discussed with the patient and or their carer and other options considered e.g. district nursing or GP follow up. Responsibility for making referrals or appointments should be clearly noted and understood by all parties.
Where return to ED Dressing Clinic, Physiotherapy or Fracture Clinic is indicated transport needs should be accommodated
Scheduling of follow up appointments at should take in to consideration the needs of the patient.
Information about communication needs are shared at the point of referral
All anticipated problems should be discussed directly with the Learning Disability Nurse Specialist, in order to ensure appropriate liaison is made with the community teams.
Surgical Pre Assessment Clinic

5.15.1 The aim is to see any person with a learning disability at the beginning of any clinic to avoid long waiting times and ideally a double appointment should be booked to ensure adequate time for communication and assessment.
5.15.2 It may be possible for the person with learning disability / carer or LD community nurse to visit prior to appointment.
5.15.3 The patient should be advised to bring their Hospital Passport with them to the appointment as this will hold important information on where reasonable adjustments need to be made.

5.15.4 The Pre Assessment check will cover :Health Promotion; Chronic illness and systems enquiry / presenting problem; Past medical History; Physical examination (if appropriate); Behaviour and Mental Health enquiry; Specific syndrome check; Family History; Social History; Accuracy of prescribed medications; Allergies; A review of co- ordination with secondary care; A review of transition arrangements where appropriate.
5.15.5 The clinic nurse is to complete the TCI preparation checklist (Appendix 6) and forward to the appropriate ward manager and LDNS for any further actions.

5.15.6 To improve interaction and understanding staff will encourage questions and answer / explain using easy terminology. Any Information leaflets issued will be explained clearly without the use of medical jargon.

5.15.7 If the admission to hospital is planned the patient's requirements for support and / or supervision must be discussed with the primary carer prior to admission and at pre- assessment. Any requirements for additional HCA or nursing support must be passed to the speciality matron. The clinic nurse will ensure that contact details are noted for further communication / discussion re supervision. It is advisable to include a contingency if for example day stay results in overnight admission.

5.15.8 Pre Assessment staff offer the patient the opportunity of visiting their allocated ward. If the patient is in agreement then the Pre Assessment staff will liaise with the appropriate ward to arrange a mutually convenient time and escort the patient and carer to the ward. The ward staff will introduce themselves and familiarise the patient with the ward environment and equipment.

5.15.9 The Specialist Assessment Form must be completed and included in the hospital record in readiness for the patient's arrival on the ward. Any communication needs must be noted. In addition clinic staff are to take a copy of the persons hospital passport, if the person with a learning disability does not have a hospital passport clinic staff are to offer one which can be completed at home if necessary.
5.15.10 The issue of consent for treatment must be considered prior to any appointment with reference to the DOH Guidance and Trust Policy.

5.15.11 If the patient is identified as having social problems; nutritional needs; diabetic concerns; pain control or smoking cessation issues then the appropriate referral will be made with the patient's agreement

5.15.12 If the patients admission date has to be postponed following assessment then the pre- assessment staff will contact the appropriate booking clerk to organise an alternative admission date and follow up for Pre Assessment.

5.15.13 If a referral is made to another department or admission from clinic is required, OPD staff must ensure that the support needs of the person with learning disability are communicated to the relevant teams. In addition please contact the (LDNS) via e mail to ensure plans are appropriate and also address all relevant concerns including crisis management / contingency planning.
Surgical wards ,Theatres and recovery
5.16.1 Quick reference guide
5.16.2 Preparation for theatre - PRE ASSESSMENT STAFF
5.16.3 The following should be discussed during the outpatient consultation and pre assessment visit between the patient, staff and if relevant family / carer.
5.16.4 Explain procedure, offer pre surgery visits, photos will assist to gain informed consent. The process should be discussed with the patient and carer before the admission.
Consider
5.16.5 The CNS LD can advise on more complex cases.
PRE ASSESSMENT AND OR WARD STAFF
5.17.1 Pre assessment team and nursing staff from the patients ward contact the appropriate theatre in advance where possible to discuss any specific patient needs.
5.17.2 This information should also be shared with the recovery team.

5.17.3 Where possible / appropriate a member of the theatre and or recovery team will visit the patient on the ward, prior to the procedure. This may be answer any questions they may have about the recovery area and have a familiar face that will be around post operatively. (For complex patients only)
5.17.4 Consider flexibility of listing for the comfort of the patient.

5.17.5 Arrange if possible for the patient to be accompanied to theatre and into the anaesthetic room by someone known to them, who will then be able to stay until the patient is anaesthetised. If local anaesthetic is used then the patient's carer may be able to stay throughout the procedure.
5.17.6 This should be discussed at the pre assessment.
Recovery

5.18.1 Once the procedure is complete the recovery nursing staff should contact the ward to notify the main carer that the procedure is complete and invite them back to the recovery room where appropriate and at the discretion of the nurse in charge .
5.18.2 Where possible the patient should be escorted back to the ward by a ward nurse who is known to them along with their carer.
5.18.3 Examples of reasonable adjustments in theatre and recovery
5.18.4 Carer access and support to the anaesthetic room and recovery area if appropriate
5.18.5 Does the patient have to wear a gown
5.18.6 Does the patient have to go straight to the ward?
5.18.7 Could the carer apply the wristband or could ward staff present to theatre staff on transfer. In patients who are very distressed this can then be applied when sedated.
Out Patient Appointments
5.19.1 When booking / preparing for clinic appointments the following consideration will be made:
Time of the appointment.
Length of the appointment.
Communication needs e.g. the need for pictures, models and other communication aids during the consultation, Hospital passport.
Consent. (Refer to Consent Policy and Mental Capacity Act).
The need for a nurse / carer to stay with the patient.
Removal of unnecessary instruments / equipment which may make the patient feel frightened. In some cases consider using another room.

5.19.2 If the patient requires a follow up appointment the date is to be arranged and flagged on the booking list that the patient will be attending again with reference to any special needs. Where follow up appointments are made at the main OPD reception, priority will be given to learning disability patients for first appointment of a clinic and double appointments where required. The needs of the carer must also be taken into consideration when booking follow up appointments where reasonably practicable.

5.19.3 On arrival to the department the receptionists will inform the Nurse in charge of the clinic, of the patient with learning disability. The clinic nurse will introduce themselves to the patient.
5.19.4 The clinic nurse will ensure that the patient with learning disability are escorted to the waiting area and made aware of the facilities e.g. toilets within the OPD .

5.19.5 The clinic nurse will request the Hospital Passport and ensure that a copy is placed in the clinical record. If the person with a learning disability if the patient does not have a hospital passport clinic staff are to offer one which can be completed at home if necessary.

5.19.6 People with learning disability have a range of abilities but will need clear explanations in plain language with the possible use of pictures. The clinic nurse will discuss the communication needs with the person with learning disability and ensure that additional resources are available where required e.g. the Hospital Communication Book which can be accessed on the intranet.
5.19.7 The clinic nurse will explain any procedures that are to take place during the appointment and how long they will take.
5.19.8 The clinic nurse will ensure that priority is given to the person with learning disability and that they are kept informed of any potential waits.
5.19.9 The clinic nurse will ensure that the consultation / examination room is appropriately prepared e.g. removing unnecessary equipment where required.
5.19.10 During the consultation all staff will need to communicate appropriately with the patient in order to communicate effectively.

5.19.11 Where an investigation e.g. x-ray is required out of the main OPD setting nursing staff will liaise with the department concerned and escort the patient to the relevant department. The nursing staff will ensure that waiting time and waiting area are appropriate and make arrangements for transfer back to the OPD if required. The nursing staff will provide explanation about the investigation.

5.19.12 If an examination or procedure is required as part of the OPD appointment, this will take place in the adjoining or appropriate examination room where the dignity and privacy of the person with learning disability can be maintained

5.19.13 If a referral is made to another department or admission from clinic is required, OPD staff must ensure that the support needs of the person with learning disability communicated to the relevant agency. In addition please contact the (LDNS) via e mail to ensure all relevant parties are aware.
Examples of reasonable adjustments in an outpatients department
5.20.1 Be prepared to have to be flexible in your approach to meet individual needs.
5.20.2 How can you make the appointment more accessible to the patient.
5.20.3 Can easy read information be sent out
5.20.4 Can you offer first / last appointment or when the clinic is less busy
5.20.5 Can a double appointment be offered to give the patient more time to discuss and understand their current health condition
5.20.6 Is there a quiet area where the patient can sit if he / she becomes distressed
5.20.7 Read the patients hospital passport
5.20.8 Use easy read information to talk through relevant information
5.20.9 If consent is required take extra time to explain- if there is doubt the patient does not understand involve carer / family MDT with best interest discussion / decision.
5.20.10 Patients / carers to be able to leave the department and be called back via mobile phone if possible when it is time to see the patient.
Diagnostics and therapeutics
5.21.1 Quick reference guide
5.21.2 Staff to be aware of learning disability flag / alert on Medway.
5.21.3 When booking the appointment consider contacting the patient in regards to making
5.21.4 reasonable adjustments to meet their needs. For example, is there a first appointment available, will they need a longer appointment, do they require any equipment eg hoist.
5.21.5 Also prompt in regards to the hospital passport (see below)
5.21.6 If  the  patient  has  complex  needs  consider  contacting  the  CNS  LD  for  additional support.
5.21.7 At the appointment the patient / carer may have a hospital passport highlighting the patients' needs to support hospital staff.
5.21.8 If the patient does not have one please signpost them to the hospital website to obtain a copy. If the patient cannot access the internet copies are available on request from the CNS LD.
5.21.9 Ensure the patient is given a full explanation of tests or investigations and where possible use easy read material to support communication.
5.21.10 If the patient is an inpatient ensure a detailed ward handover is given.
5.21.11 If the patient requires another appointment ensure it is written down clearly on a card with date and time separate e.g 1pm (afternoon) on Wednesday 5th December 2014
Examples of reasonable adjustments:
Admin staff to contact patient prior to appointment to discuss needs.
Double appointments
First / last appointments
Quiet waiting area
Do they really need to wear a gown?
Consider use of mild local anaesthetic for blood tests
Pre appointment visits to the department to familiarise themselves with the
Department / equipment.
Eye Unit Care Pathway
Quick reference guide

5.24.1 Learning disability diagnosis should be identified in G.P referral letter and flagged on Medway. If the patient has learning disabilities or autism and there is no flag please inform the Adult Safeguarding team who can add to medway.

5.24.2 Eye unit manager to ensure reasonable adjustments are implemented. They have access to information relating to when people with learning disabilities are attending appointments in their clinic. When booking appointments please consider the length of time allocated as people with learning disabilities may require a double slot.

5.24.3 For the safety and comfort of the patient attending the clinic it may be necessary to alter the patient's appointment time in order to minimise any patient anxiety that may occur by lengthy waiting in an unfamiliar environment.
5.24.4 Please also offer a quieter waiting area where possible.
5.24.5 Please consider if it would be more appropriate for eye drops to be administered prior to attending. This will reduce the waiting time in the clinic.

5.24.6 At the appointment the patient / carer should bring their completed hospital passport. If they do not have one outpatient staff to offer blank one or direct to hospital website for electronic version.
5.24.7 Advise to bring the completed up to date copy to hospital on admission if required.
5.24.8 Consent is required in all areas of care and treatment.
5.24.9 Consent cannot be given on behalf of another adult unless: appointed deputy (court of protection) / power of attorney or stated in advanced decisions.
5.24.10 All patients must be treated as equal, having the same rights to care and should not be excluded from treatment unless clinically indicated.
5.24.11 It should not be assumed that patients with a learning disability cannot give informed consent.
5.24.12 Medical and nursing staff should assess the capacity of the patient to give consent along with people who know them best. Be aware that capacity can fluctuate and is decision specific.
5.24.13 All care given must be clearly in the patients best interests, ultimately the attending Dr will lead consultation with family, carers and MDT in decisions to proceed without consent.
5.24.14 If no family / friends IMCA should be sought to assist a patient who lacks capacity with decisions relating to serious medical procedures or an alternative home.
Examples of reasonable adjustments in an outpatients department:
How can you make the appointment more accessible to the patient?
Be prepared to have to be flexible in your approach to meet individual needs.
Can easy read information be sent out prior to the appointment?
Can you offer first / last appointment or when the clinic is less busy ?
Can a double appointment be offered to give the patient more time to discuss and understand their current health condition?
Is there a quiet area where the patient can sit if he / she becomes distressed?
Read the patient's hospital passport.
Use easy read information to talk through relevant information.
If consent is required take extra time to explain- if there is doubt the patient does not understand involve carer / family MDT with best interest discussion / decision.
Patients / carers to be able to leave the department and be called back via mobile phone if possible when it is time to see the patient.
Endoscopy Care Pathway
5.26.1 Quick reference guide
5.26.2 Appointment Planning

5.26.4 Highlight to pre assessment clinic that the patient has learning disabilities
5.26.5 Learning disability should be identified in G.P referral letter and flagged on Medway / Lorenzo.
5.26.6 Endoscopy manager to ensure reasonable adjustments are implemented. They have access to information relating to when people with learning disabilities have appointments in their clinic.

5.26.10 Ensure face to face appointment is given to the patient.

5.26.13 Is there a quiet area where the patient can sit if he / she becomes distressed
5.26.14 Read the patients hospital passport. Advise the patient to bring completed up to date hospital passport on admission.
5.26.15 If the patient does not have a hospital passport, offer them one or signpost to internet for an electronic copy.
5.26.16 Complete learning disability specialist communication assessment if appropriate (Appendix 1)
5.26.17 Complete learning disability risk assessment tool (Appendix 5)
5.26.18 The patient may require additional time to understand process and planned treatment.
5.26.19 Offer accessible information i.e. photos to assist patients understanding.
5.26.20 If consent is required take extra time to explain- if there is doubt the patient does not understand involve carer / family MDT with best interest discussion / decision.
5.26.21 Consent is required in all areas of care and treatment.
5.26.22 Consent cannot be given on behalf of another adult unless: appointed deputy (court of protection) / power of attorney or stated in advanced decisions.
5.26.23 All patients must be treated as equal; having the same rights to care and should not be excluded from treatment unless clinically indicated.
5.26.24 It should not be assumed that patients with a learning disability cannot give informed consent.
5.26.25 Medical staff should assess the capacity of the patient to give consent along with people who know them best. Be aware that capacity can fluctuate and is decision specific.
5.26.26 All care given must be clearly in the patients best interests, ultimately the attending Dr will lead consultation with family, carers and MDT in decisions to proceed without consent.
5.26.27 If no family / friends IMCA should be sought to assist a patient who lacks capacity with decisions relating to serious medical procedures.
5.26.28 Any concerns regarding capacity and consent should be documented and if appropriate additional support may be required. Refer to MCA policy.
5.26.29 Ensure where possible all diagnostic tests are carried out in one appointment.
5.26.30 Patient may not be compliant with procedures such as blood tests; reasonable adjustments will need to be made.
5.26.31 Pre assessment nurse to consider plan for bowel prep / NBM / and also reasonable adjustments required to enable cannulation if required.
5.26.32 Pre assessment nurse to complete TCI checklist and handover plan to endoscopy team.

5.26.33 Consider if the patient will require supervision / carer present following sedation. The patient may not have anyone to support as required overnight. Contact the social care team for the appropriate locality to inform them of the potential need for short term care review.
Day of Procedure
5.27.1 Ensure team are aware of pre assessment care plan and reasonable adjustments and are prepared to put them into place.
5.27.2 Ensure team have read the patients hospital passport and SPA assessment if appropriate.
5.27.3 Introduce self to patient / family / carer where appropriate to discuss plan.
5.27.4 Depending on procedure and plan in place – follow pre assessment plan
5.27.5 e.g carer to support throughout, numbing cream applied prior to cannula insertion, distraction techniques are available and accessible
5.27.6 Ensure good communication with the patient and or their carer throughout, including discharge.
5.27.7 Complete day stay learning disability checklist.
DNA Appointments

5.28.1 It is essential that patients, who are vulnerable, for whatever reason, have their needs identified as part of the referral process to the Trust, or at the point of requesting diagnostics or requesting an admission, with the patient's consent. This group of patients includes patients with learning disabilities.

5.28.2 In addition, these patients should not be discharged on their first DNA, another appointment should be offered and possible safeguarding concerns that may be relevant. The consultant's team may also wish to follow up directly with the patient or GP before offering the appointment; this should be judged on a case by case basis.
5.28.3 For further details please refer to the trusts Patient Access Policy.
Maternity

5.29.1 Once an expectant mother has been identified as having a learning disability, a referral should be considered by the safeguarding midwife at the earliest stage as to whether input from LD specialist nurses (acute and / or community) would be appropriate.

5.29.2 A high level of professional support is to be extended to both mother and baby to ensure on going parenting assessments/monitoring/education can be carried out and support offered where necessary for a positive outcome to be achieved.

5.29.3 The Specialist Midwife for Vulnerable Women will assist the midwives with care planning and multi-agency liaison to ensure that there is a robust plan to support women with learning disabilities (LD) and their babies.
5.29.4 It is recommended that the named midwife or a small group of midwives follow the patient throughout the pregnancy and birth where possible to provide continuity of care.
The First Visit
5.30.1 At the first visit the pregnancy and birth plan should include information regarding:
5.30.2 Main carer/s
5.30.3 Any other services / agencies who should be involved
5.30.4 Copy of hospital support plan / health action plan
5.30.5 Special requirements for subsequent appointments
5.30.6 Plans should commence in preparation for following birth and discharge
Education
5.31.1 All plans and education for example parent craft/parent education will be provided on an individualised basis and will involve partner and identified persons / carers throughout.
5.31.2 Additional support / visits will be planned if identified this may include the health visitor, GP; LD nurses, social workers and midwives.
The Birth Plan
5.32.1 The midwife and LD nurse where appropriate, will accompany the woman to her consultant clinic appointments.

5.32.2 The Specialist Midwife for Vulnerable Women will assist the midwives with care planning and multi-agency liaison to ensure that there is a robust plan to support expectant women with learning difficulties and their babies.
5.32.3 A copy of the pregnancy and birth plan will be inserted into the case notes along with the patient's own copy.
5.32.4 On admission for the birth where feasible a midwife who has been involved should attend. Provision will be made for special visiting for the partner and carers to enable support and education.
5.32.5 The length of stay will vary to each individual. Discharge arrangements should be made in conjunction with all involved.
5.32.6 Additional follow up appointments will be arranged according for each individual. An emergency contact will be provided to the patient, partner and or main carers.
Inpatient Admission
5.33.1 Any person with a learning disability who requires admission will be clearly identified via tele tracking by the requesting area to ensure appropriate and timely allocation of a bed.

5.33.2 The bed allocation team will consider the need for the person with learning disability to be supported during admission .In some cases the carer may wish to stay with the patient and in these cases every effort must be made to try and transfer the patient to a side room. The carer's sleeping arrangements and any other requirements must be discussed and met, wherever possible by the admitting ward.

5.33.3 The bed allocation team will inform the admitting ward of learning disability diagnosis and any identified or enhanced needs including specialist equipment, supervision requirements and any other reasonable adjustments that have been identified.
5.33.4 Patients with Learning disabilities are not to be considered for ward transfer unless clinically appropriate.

5.33.5 On admission the Named Nurse should check provision has been made to meet all anticipated care needs identified by ward staff, or identified by the carer if they have agreed to provide guidance on this. Advice on anticipated care needs may also be given by the (LDNS). This includes the completion of the hospital passport (Appendix
1) the Specialist Assessment (Appendix 2) and the learning disability admission checklist (appendix 7a, 7b (day stay))

5.33.6 Where possible, the Named Nurse and main carer should undertake an admission assessment of the patient's care needs. Full use of the expertise of the main carer (if appropriate) should be made in order to facilitate a thorough assessment. The assessment should take account of the individual's physical, psychological, social and cultural needs. This should inherently consider a person's needs with regard to the protection of individuality, vulnerability and dignity.

5.33.7 Particular note should be made of the patient's medication regime, including the form of the preparation, times and methods of administration (which may be tailored very specifically to the individual patient). These details should be discussed with relevant medical staff and the Clinical Pharmacist in order to ensure, unless clinically inappropriate, continuity of medicating practices during hospitalisation.
5.33.8 The Named Nurse will find out from carers, relatives etc. what the patient was usually like before they became ill.
5.33.9 It is important for the ward to have contact details for carers and / or relatives and to know the order/ circumstances in which to call them.
5.33.10 The anticipated length of stay and care needs following treatment should also be estimated at admission and communicated to the patient and main carer by the named nurse.
5.33.11 If appropriate a care plan should be developed which also identifies any specific requirements relating to aspects of care such as positioning, sensory stimulation or

feeding requirements. This should be in line with any care plans that are used in the community, it may be appropriate to transfer these to be continued in the ward environment. The care plan should be discussed with and made available to the main carer (with the patient's consent).
5.33.12 If the main carer is unable to contribute fully to this assessment, the nurse may contact the (LDNS) for advice and assistance in the assessment process.

5.33.13 If carers and relatives choose to assist, then their welfare must be considered e.g. relieving them for breaks. Drinks should be provided. Consideration should be given to providing a room for breaks / making drinks / family members to meet away from the patient to discuss treatment options or future needs

5.33.14 If the main carer is not able to be involved in the direct care of the individual, then they need a communication system to ensure they are kept informed of all developments and treatments, and know who to contact on the ward for updates.
5.33.15 Remember to include the patient in conversations and consultations.

5.33.16 For patients being admitted to an inpatient bed or being transferred from another area of the hospital the receiving ward manager or senior nurse in charge must take responsibility for arranging a multidisciplinary meeting if appropriate. The primary carer where appropriate should be involved in the MDT to ensure that there is a sharing of information and a mutual understanding of responsibilities for care within the MDT.
Risk management
5.34.1 People with learning disability are at significantly higher risk of adverse events happening to them whilst they are in hospital
5.34.2 People with a learning disability may have lack of or low insight into everyday dangers. Care must be taken with sharp objects, medicines, hot water, hot food and drink, open windows etc.
5.34.3 Reasonable adjustments in the form of extra supervision may need to be made for patients who at risk to themselves or others.

5.34.4 The Trust has a learning disability risk assessment tool to support identification of specific risks and the implementation of care bundles. This assessment must be completed on admission for every person with learning disability admitted to the Trust and kept in their health records. See Appendix 5

5.34.5 This risk assessment is to be completed by the admitting nurse within  hours of arrival to the inpatient ward. The risk assessment should be reviewed every  hours or if the patients circumstances change e.g ward transfer.

5.34.6 It will be important to consider where the individual is best placed when admitted to the ward area. If additional monitoring is required, but the patient is assessed as not requiring 1:1 support, to reduce any specific risk the patient may be best placed in a bay area with their bed closest to the nurses' station.

5.34.7 On occasions due to the complexity of needs and risk identified (which may include extreme anxiety and behaviour that challenge services) it is only suitable for the patient's own/familiar paid care team to provide this 1:1 or even 2:1 support for the patient during their admission.
5.34.8 The admitting nurse must discuss / contact the primary carer or residential home (if relevant) to assess the patient's needs for support and / or supervision.

5.34.9 Agreement must be reached at the earliest possible stage with the primary carer as to what, if any, involvement they wish to have with the care of the person with learning disability in the ward environment. Ward nurses need to work in partnership with people with learning disability and their carers / families.

5.34.10 In some cases formal agreement needs to be reached on who is responsible for and will provide this support, who will pay for the support and what the legal requirements are for the carer's transfer of support during the patient's admission.

5.34.11 This process will provide support to the nursing team to ensure that the individual receives the level of support they require to ensure their safety and to ensure all the necessary checks and requirements are in place to protect the individual patient, hospital team and individual carer providing the agreed support.
5.34.12 This process does not apply to family carers, relatives or friends (unpaid carers).
Identifying the need for 1:1 special, for people with learning disabilities:

5.35.1 When a patient with a learning disability is admitted to the hospital, the admitting nurse should complete the Learning Disability Rapid Risk Assessment (Appendix 5) with the individual and their family/ carers to identify any areas of risk.
5.35.2 For planned admissions, assessment for supervision should form part of the pre- assessment process. This should be notified to the matron for the speciality in advance.

5.35.3 If a medium or high risk score is indicated and the patient has significant risks in relation to personal safety i.e. Fall from bed, removal of drips/ drains leading to potential poor health outcome, or significant behaviours or anxiety that will challenge services.

5.35.4 If the patient's risks are mainly due to the removal of medical devices, wandering due to poor orientation, or falls, and there is no indication for the need for the patient's own care team to provide support, the nurse should highlight /discuss the need for a 1:1 nurse. All discussions and decisions should be documented clearly in the patient's health record.

5.35.5 If the 1:1 is unable to be filled this should be recorded in the patient's health record, discussed with the senior nurse on duty, and steps taken to reduce risk as far as possible i.e. increased observation, relocation of bed closer to nurse's station, use of / nursing team already on ward to increase level of monitoring and supervision etc. This should also be recorded via the incident reporting system.
5.35.6 The need for the 1:1 special for all patients with a learning disability should be reviewed on a  hour basis, due to the potential for decreased or increased risk as their health improves.
5.35.7 Agreeing the need and funding for the support to be provided from the patient's own care team.

5.35.8 If the risk assessment indicate a significant risk to the patient's own safety, the safety of other patients and the hospital staff due to anxiety, behaviour, severe hospital phobia etc. (highly likely in the case where patients have diagnosed autism or significant self-injurious behaviour/ behaviour that may become challenging). The only option may be that the patient's own care team provide the 1:1 support required to assist the patient to reduce their anxiety and manage their behavioural needs.

5.35.9 It should never be presumed that the carers will automatically do this, as they may not be funded to provide this level of support or have the additional staffing required to release carers to stay at the hospital.
5.35.10 The acute hospital will provide and fund additional staffing required.
5.35.11 This will need to be discussed by the admitting nurse with the ward sister/charge
5.35.12 Nurse and the senior nurse responsible for the ward and a care plan will need to be agreed between the patient's own care team and the hospital.
5.35.13 The Clinical Site Manager should be contacted out of hours instead of the
5.35.14 Speciality senior matron for emergency / short notice authorisation.
5.35.15 Where a deprivation of liberty may occur, the Policy for the Deprivation of Liberty
5.35.16 Safeguards CM61 must be followed. Where Standard Authorisation for Deprivation of

5.35.17 Liberty may exist in the patient's usual residential care, this authorisation is not transferable to the Acute Trust. Deprivation of Liberty is the term used when a person's freedom is taken away through restraint, restriction of movement and control, including the threatened or actual use of force. (Please see MCA and DOLS policy).
5.35.18 Where bed rails are requested or considered for use with a patient with learning disability the Trust Policy for the Safe and Effective use of Bed Rails must be followed.
Postural care management in hospital

5.36.1 Many people with profound and multiple learning disabilities have regular and sometimes lengthy stays in hospital. The problems this can cause in terms of body distortion are only anecdotally reported.

5.36.2 Generally in hospitals, there is no recorded information about positioning and, therefore it is not addressed. Hospital passports should include details about how a person needs to be positioned at different times; for example, for eating and drinking or at night-time, and all staff need to be aware of these different needs.

5.36.3 It can be difficult for people to take their own equipment, such as night positioning systems, into hospital due to problems with space and laundry. The special sheets that some people use are not able to cope with high temperature washes and may not be returned to the correct person. If someone with a postural care programme is admitted to hospital and likely to stay for more than a few days then ideally their physiotherapist should write some temporary guidelines for their stay which may include advice on recreating a positioning system using available materials such as pillows.
5.36.4 This case study illustrates some of the problems that can occur when an individual with postural care needs is admitted to hospital.

5.36.5 ‘When Simon was admitted to hospital, his family took his positioning system in. They were told by hospital staff that it could not be used as it was an infection control risk. However it later transpired that this information was incorrect. When equipment belongs to one person there should not be any issues around infection control.'

5.36.6 ‘Simon's hospital passport flagged his positioning needs but it was not read and he was not positioned correctly during his admission and spent the majority of time lying on a flat mattress. Simon ended up in hospital for over 3 months and in this time his posture deteriorated to the extent that he no longer fitted properly in his moulded wheelchair. It also meant it became more difficult to wash and dress him. He had to start taking pain killers due to the muscle pain and a referral had to be made for the special seating service for adjustments to be made to his moulded wheelchair.
5.36.7 If you have concerns regarding a patients postural management please speak to the care provider, Physiotherapist or Learning disability liaison nurse.
Carers

5.37.1 During the admission process the staff should discuss and clearly identify with the carer, roles and responsibilities. Some carers may want to undertake some aspects of care; this is voluntary and staff should be aware that any care needs of the patient are always the responsibility of the hospital staff. Where carers wish to deliver care to the patient whilst they are in hospital then the boundaries about what is expected of hospital staff and what is safe for a carer to do in a hospital setting should be openly discussed, agreed and documented. This can be recorded in the carer's passport pages included In the patients hospital passport.

5.37.2 Staff will view carers as partners in the provision of healthcare by respecting and listening to their views – longer-term carers are likely to have valuable expertise and be highly skilled in caring for the patient.
5.37.3 Staff will acknowledge carers' own needs, ensuring that they have the relevant information and resources needed to plan effectively for their caring role.
5.37.4 Ensure that carers are involved (rather than just informed) at all stages of the patient's journey.
5.37.5 This would include:
Planning for admission
Communication on patient progress during hospital episode
Making the decision to discharge the patient
Discussing and agreeing practical alterations and preparations for the discharge at home. Carers may need time to make arrangements
Agreeing the time of discharge, even the estimated date of discharge giving the carer sufficient notice of the patient's discharge.

5.37.6 Healthcare staff must consider the needs of relatives and carers and support them appropriately. The patients hospital passport has a page dedicated to the needs of that individuals carer whilst they are in hospital.
5.37.7 These considerations will include
Sleeping – access to “Z” bed
Access to toilet and washing facilities
Access to food and drink
Respite break support as required but offered at a minimum of 4 hourly
Ensure carer does not provide care 24 hours a day

5.37.8 Carers themselves may have health needs that require consideration in planning care and / or discharge of the patient with learning disability particularly if there has been a new or deteriorating condition in either the patient or carers health.
End of life

5.38.1 People with learning disabilities have the same palliative care needs as the general population, including symptom management, coming to terms with illness and dying, and making decisions about their wishes. But they may also have additional needs due to their disability.
5.38.2 There are lots of issues that can be challenging for people with learning disabilities towards the end of their life. People with learning disabilities:
have more physical and mental health problems and these can be complex
are more likely to be vulnerable and socially isolated
have difficulty accessing healthcare systems
are more likely to be diagnosed with cancer later which means they have a poorer prognosis
have a higher risk of dementia – people with Down's syndrome may also have dementia at a much younger age than average
may have communication difficulties which make it harder to express their symptoms
may find it harder to express their wishes about their care.
5.38.3 Providing the best person-centred care involves identifying and addressing these additional needs and challenges.
5.38.4 Making sure end of life care is person centred is key and our teams should be part of a wider plan led by the community learning disability and palliative care services.
5.38.5 However it is recognised that this may not always be the case and acute care staff may be the first professionals involved.

5.38.6 Treat each person as an individual and get to know them and those around them well. Family members and professional carers may have been involved in the person's care for a long time. Learn about the person's needs and preferences, what they can do independently and what they need support with.

5.38.7 The Mental Capacity Act (England and Wales) 2005, is designed to protect and empower people who may lack the mental capacity to make their own decisions about their care and treatment. You may find it useful to refer to the trust Capacity and consent policy.

5.38.8 Consideration must be given to the provision of training, information and support for family members and carers, for example, in medication, pain, nutrition and hydration, to enable the person to die where they wish.

5.38.9 Make sure that key members of the person's support network have the knowledge, confidence and understanding to communicate with the person about their illness and death. This includes being able to talk to the person about symptoms, pain management and their preferences about resuscitation.

5.38.10 Sometimes family members and carers will want you to withhold information from the person. This is a challenging situation. Treat each case on an individual basis and consider what effect the information will have on the person.

5.38.11 People with learning disabilities should have access to all the services that people without learning disabilities have. Give individuals or their carers information on local services including chaplaincy, hospice day care and complementary therapy.

5.38.12 Mainstream end of life care services should make reasonable adjustments to support the person, their family members, friends and carers and other people they live with, throughout palliative and end of life care and bereavement. The patients hospital passport may contain information relating to their wishes.

5.38.13 It has been recognised that nationally DNACPR forms were not always completed appropriately. Some reviews found that Part one of the DNACPR forms had been completed, with the reason documented as to why resuscitation would be inappropriate as “quality of life” and ‘learning disability'.

5.38.14 The trust policy for Decisions Regarding Attempting Cardiopulmonary Resuscitation (DNACPR) for Patients states that any DNACPR decision should always take into account the individual circumstances of the patient. Decisions should not be based on assumptions made solely on factors such as age, disability or the professional's subjective view of the patient's quality of life. The policy also covers how teams support individuals who do not have capacity, and the process for reviewing concerns or challenges in respect of the completion of DNACPR documents.

5.38.15 Any health care practitioner can raise concerns around the completion of these documents and it is essential that all clinical staff raise concerns immediately to the patients lead clinician for urgent review.

5.38.16 The learning disability nurse will review (at the earliest opportunity) inpatient DNACPR forms for inpatients with a learning disability to ensure they are competed without bias or prejudice and follow the principles of the Mental Capacity act if required. If it is found that the DNACPR or Treatment escalation plan has not been completed appropriately the Learning Disability liaison nurse will advise the person who has completed the form of their concerns immediately and ensure the plan is reviewed appropriately. This will also be reported as an incident via our internal reporting structures for further review and follow up. If the patients care has been delayed or omitted a safeguarding concern would be raised where safeguarding thresholds are met.
5.38.17 In addition DNACPR forms are also reviewed as part of the structured judgment process for all deaths that occur within the hospital of people with a learning disability.

5.38.18 Accessible information for patients is key to supporting decision making and understanding new information. To empower our patient group we have created an easy read information leaflet to support understanding and discussion around DNACPR. In addition to promote appropriate and timely discussion around such difficult issues, we have now included an end of life section in the hospital passport.

5.38.19 To ensure appropriate escalation and transparency around clinical practice all concerns relating to DNACPR are raised to the appropriate leads and trust governance groups. This is in addition to sharing for wider learning with the LEDER steering group.
Discharge from hospital
5.39.1 In addition to the procedures laid down in the Trust's discharge policy, supplementary actions may need to be taken.
5.39.2 It is possible that the patient will require additional after care.

5.39.3 It is essential that all follow up appointments are discussed with the patient, primary carer or professional to ensure a clear understanding of who will be responsible for the patient's care once they have left hospital. Clear follow up instructions must be given to the patient or primary carer including contact numbers and changes to care and treatment, including new medication.
5.39.4 A copy of the discharge summary should be provided to the patient, carer or professional to assist in this understanding if requested.

5.39.5 The patient, primary carer or professional must be involved in discussions relating to discharge arrangements, and to ensure effective co-ordination if a multidisciplinary discharge meeting is required, their attendance is crucial.
5.39.6 At discharge the patient, primary carer must be given contact details of the community support team and any other appropriate resource within the community.

5.39.7 If the patient has no representative, family member or friend it may be appropriate to request the involvement of an Independent Mental Capacity Advocate (IMCA). These may be contacted via the Discharge Team

5.39.8 All anticipated problems should be discussed directly with the Discharge coordinator and the Learning Disability Nurse Specialist, in order to ensure appropriate liaison is made with the community teams.
Mortality review process
5.40.1 All internal hospital deaths of people with a learning disability are reported to the LEDER national database for external review.
5.40.2 All internal hospital deaths of people with a learning disability are reviewed initially by the relevant Medical Examiner.
5.40.3 All internal hospital deaths of people with a learning disability are automatically referred for a structured judgement review by an appropriate Consultant.
5.40.4 In addition all internal hospital deaths of people with a learning disability are automatically referred for a structured judgement review by the Learning disability Liaison nurse specialist.
5.40.5 All areas of good practice and areas for development are shared with the appropriate teams and reported to the MSE hospital group Safeguarding committee in common.
Sharing Information
5.41.1 All patients have a right to privacy and to control information about themselves. Where the person lacks capacity, this right must be balanced with protection of their interests.

5.41.2 Although carers will be involved in best interests decisions there should not be widespread disclosure of personal health information without the person's valid consent and information should be shared on a need to know basis.

5.41.3 Information pertinent to any change in the person's support needs should be shared with learning disability care staff, but detailed clinical information should be treated sensitively and disclosed only when necessary and to those who need to know it.
5.41.4 It must not be assumed that the person's next of kin is the primary carer. Some people

with learning disabilities live in supported environments and the care provider may be responsible for the health and wellbeing of the service user. Care staff would expect to be involved in best interest's discussions where the person with a learning disability lacks capacity.

5.41.5 All patients should be consulted about who they wish to be included in discussions about clinical matters. Clinical information will be shared as appropriate by professional colleagues, i.e. therapist to therapist, etc. to ensure continuity of care.

5.41.6 The duty of candour still needs to be considered please refer to MSEPO-19014 Policy for Management of Incidents and MSEPO-19015 Procedure Report Management of Incidents and Serious Incidents and patient's communication wishes must be considered during this process
Training
Heads of departments are responsible for ensuring compliance by making necessary provisions for individual Staff to attend training sessions.
Learning Disability awareness training is statutory and staff are mapped appropriately. Advice & Support
